results.title: D-evolution
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Searle, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
When the Huntress Shar catches her prey, the gorgeous Khan, in a lush forest glade, she thinks she’s come to the end of her hunt. But it’s only the beginning…
Combining traditional and contemporary visual effects tools, D-evolution attempts to tell a story about technology and reality, using technology itself to shape the visuals of the film.
Cast: Kate Beahan, Aaron Pedersen, Alana De Roma, Anni Finsterer
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicholas Searle, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS

results.title: Louise
results.creator_credit: Kelly Schilling, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short documentary about a woman named Louise Mitchie who was born as a replacement child - a child conceived and born in order to help with the grief experienced by parents who had lost their first child in infancy.

results.title: Grey
results.creator_credit: Kelly Schilling, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Aboriginal couple Annika and Randle have very different ideas on how to approach the Sydney Harbour Bridge reconciliation march between black and white Australians. Annika thinks that they should be up there on that bridge showing their support while Randle prefers to show his support on a smaller, more personal scale.
After the march a white woman collapses and, while Randle is off calling for an ambulance, Annika stays with the woman. It is here that she is forced to confront her own prejudice and ultimately acknowledge that she just may be one of the biggest hypocrites of all.
Cast: Janine Matthews, Laurence Clifford, Victoria Longley
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kelly Schilling, Joe Weatherstone, Steven McGregor and AFTRS

results.title: Surface tension
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Karena Slaninka and Moira Moss
results.brief_description: Freida has something to tell Nick, but she doesn’t know what she feels or how to express it. The unspoken is the source of a tension that grows and grows and eventually must burst like a bubble rising to the surface. Original format 16mm.
results.description: Freida has something to tell Nick, but she doesn’t know what she feels or how to express it. The unspoken is the source of a tension that grows and grows and eventually must burst like a bubble rising to the surface. Original format 16mm.

results.title: Fly Peewee fly (A)
results.creator_credit: Sally Riley, Adrienne Parr, SBS Independent and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boy, Robbie is in the midst of the conflict between his father and his grandmother. Robbie’s grandmother is white and wants to give Robbie every advantage, while Robbie’s aboriginal father is searching for his own identity and place. A warm story about fragile but meaningful family relationships.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sally Riley, Adrienne Parr, SBS Independent and Film Australia

results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Peter Kordyl, Mark Bin Bakar, Marion Benjamin, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Kordyl, Mark Bin Bakar, Marion Benjamin, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees

In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.

results.title: Round up
results.brief_description: Round Up follows the journey of two country boys who find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. Here in this unfamiliar environment, they may learn that they are not as different as they first thought.
results.description: Round Up follows the journey of two country boys who find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. Here in this unfamiliar environment, they may learn that they are not as different as they first thought.

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.

results.title: Round up (A)
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague and Core Original Productions
results.brief_description: Two country boys, one white and the other aboriginal find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. What they learn on the journey that they embark upon through unfamiliar territory, is that they are not as different as they first thought.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague and Core Original Productions

details.label: Subject categories
display_values: Aboriginal Australia → Aboriginal Australians - Producers and directors

results.title: From sand to celluloid (A)
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.
